articles.headline: Something Went ‘Very Wrong’ at G.M., Chief Says
articles.snippet: Mary T. Barra announced recalls affecting 1.7 million more vehicles, and in a message to employees vowed to change internal procedures to address safety issues.
articles.abstract: Mary T. Barra announced recalls affecting 1.7 million more vehicles, and in a message to employees vowed to change internal procedures to address safety issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mary T. Barra, General Motors’ chief executive, announced another round of wide-ranging recalls on Monday, a sign that the company was moving with a new sense of urgency on safety problems after it disclosed a decade-long failure to fix a defect tied to 12 deaths.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Christopher Jensen

articles.headline: Earning Their Stripes as Umpires and Referees
articles.snippet: The few who make it to the big leagues or top college levels can make six-figure salaries, while others can make good part-time incomes.
articles.abstract: The few who make it to the big leagues or top college levels can make six-figure salaries, while others can make good part-time incomes.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2012, when David Martinez left a job teaching math at a high school in Bayonne, N.J., to try to become a professional baseball umpire, he understood that the numbers might not add up.

articles.headline: Helping Women Get Back in the Game
articles.snippet: Programs to help women return to the work force after a break to care for children or aging parents are increasing in the fields of finance and law.
articles.abstract: Programs to help women return to the work force after a break to care for children or aging parents are increasing in the fields of finance and law.
articles.lead_paragraph: Andrea Chermayeff planned to go back to work when the youngest of her four children enrolled in school last fall. With a Harvard M.B.A. and experience at a private equity firm, she had the credentials to return to Wall Street. The only problem was explaining a 15-year gap on her résumé.

articles.headline: CNN’s Ratings Surge Covering the Mystery of the Missing Airliner
articles.snippet: Anderson Cooper’s CNN show at 8 p.m. beat Bill O’Reilly’s highly rated show on Fox News three nights last week in the coveted audience aged 18 to 54. That was a first for CNN.
articles.abstract: Anderson Cooper’s CNN show at 8 p.m. beat Bill O’Reilly’s highly rated show on Fox News three nights last week in the coveted audience aged 18 to 54. That was a first for CNN.
articles.lead_paragraph: On CNN, the plane rises from misty clouds accompanied by an eerie background score while anchors offer intriguing details — some new, some days old — of the disappearance of Flight 370. The reports, broadcast continually, often are augmented by speculation — sometimes fevered, sometimes tempered — about where the flight might have come to rest. And viewers are eating it up.

articles.headline: Tesla Fights for a Place to Park
articles.snippet: New Jersey is the latest state to bar Tesla’s stores for its electric vehicles under laws that favor independent dealerships.
articles.abstract: New Jersey is the latest state to bar Tesla’s stores for its electric vehicles under laws that favor independent dealerships.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tesla Motors, the maker of high-end all-electric cars, has made no secret of its ambitions to transform the auto industry, through methods ranging from the radical design of its cars to its free network of charging stations to repairing its sedans remotely by computer. But now, Tesla’s lofty goals have run into a more ordinary roadblock: the ubiquitous local auto dealer.

articles.headline: Foreign Investors in Russia Vital to Sanctions Debate
articles.snippet: More than a quarter of a trillion dollars has flowed into the coffers of Russia Inc., part of a broad push by yield-hungry investors into emerging markets.
articles.abstract: More than a quarter of a trillion dollars has flowed into the coffers of Russia Inc., part of a broad push by yield-hungry investors into emerging markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the United States and Europe move to punish Russia for its conduct in Ukraine and Crimea with official sanctions, a subtle approach could prove more powerful: pressuring large global investors to reduce their sizable holdings in Russia.

articles.headline: Three Years of Strife and Cruelty Puts Syria in Free Fall
articles.snippet: At the start of the fourth year since Syrians rose up in a peaceful movement that turned to arms, a snapshot of the country presents the harsh truth that Syria’s descent is only accelerating.
articles.abstract: At the start of the fourth year since Syrians rose up in a peaceful movement that turned to arms, a snapshot of the country presents the harsh truth that Syria’s descent is only accelerating.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT — Day after day, the Syrian civil war has ground down a cultural and political center of the Middle East, turning it into a stage for disaster and cruelty on a nearly incomprehensible scale. Families are brutalized by their government and by jihadists claiming to be their saviors as nearly half of Syrians — many of them children — have been driven from their homes.

articles.headline: A Campaign Inquiry in Utah Is the Watchdogs’ Worst Case
articles.snippet: Documents show that a former Utah attorney general sought to transform his office into a defender of payday loan companies that had helped bankroll his election.
articles.abstract: Documents show that a former Utah attorney general sought to transform his office into a defender of payday loan companies that had helped bankroll his election.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is the nightmare scenario for those who worry that the modern campaign finance system has opened up new frontiers of political corruption: A candidate colludes with wealthy corporate backers and promises to defend their interests if elected. The companies spend heavily to elect the candidate, but hide the money by funneling it through a nonprofit group. And the main purpose of the nonprofit appears to be getting the candidate elected.

articles.headline: Putin Reclaims Crimea for Russia and Bitterly Denounces the West
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said he was reversing what he described as a historical mistake, declaring, “Crimea has always been an integral part of Russia in the hearts and minds of people.”
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said he was reversing what he described as a historical mistake, declaring, “Crimea has always been an integral part of Russia in the hearts and minds of people.”
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin reclaimed Crimea as a part of Russia on Tuesday, reversing what he described as a historic injustice inflicted by the Soviet Union 60 years ago and brushing aside international condemnation that could leave Russia isolated for years to come.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Ellen Barry

articles.headline: China’s Rapid Growth Hits the Brakes
articles.snippet: Weak housing prices for February add to the debate over the country’s commitment to economic reforms.
articles.abstract: Weak housing prices for February add to the debate over the country’s commitment to economic reforms.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — New pockets of economic weakness in China emerged on Tuesday, as the collapse of a highly indebted real estate developer and weak home sales pointed to a slowdown in the sprawling property sector.

articles.headline: Murky Path for the Fed as Yellen Takes Reins
articles.snippet: Observers say Janet L. Yellen, the new chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, is taking over as the relatively clear decisions of the financial crisis must give way to more complex ones.
articles.abstract: Observers say Janet L. Yellen, the new chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, is taking over as the relatively clear decisions of the financial crisis must give way to more complex ones.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen is taking over the leadership of the Federal Reserve on the cusp of a more challenging period for the central bank.

articles.headline: G.M. Chief Steps Up to Handle Safety Questions
articles.snippet: Mary T. Barra, barely two months into her job as G.M.’s chief executive, pledged to fix faulty ignition switches linked to 12 deaths and sought to restore some measure of confidence.
articles.abstract: Mary T. Barra, barely two months into her job as G.M.’s chief executive, pledged to fix faulty ignition switches linked to 12 deaths and sought to restore some measure of confidence.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — It was a moment unlike any other at General Motors: the top executive stepping — personally and publicly — into the middle of one of the gravest safety problems in the company’s history.
